name: Bone marrow
description: Bone marrow is the primary site of hematopoiesis (blood cell formation). It consists of hematopoietic cells and adipose tissue within a trabecular bone framework.

features: Hematopoietic Cords: Clusters of developing blood cells
Sinusoids: Discontinuous capillaries (allow cell entry)
Megakaryocytes: Giant cells with multilobed complex nuclei (produce platelets)
Adipocytes (content increases with age - Yellow Marrow)
Erythroblastic islets and Granulocytic precursors
theory.examTips: Scan for the largest cells first = Megakaryocytes. Red Marrow = High cellularity. Yellow Marrow = Mostly fat. Erythroid precursors have round dark nuclei. Myeloid precursors have indented/lobed nuclei.

name: Lymph node
description: Lymph nodes are encapsulated lymphoid organs that filter lymph. They have a cortex (lymphoid follicles) and a medulla (cords and sinuses).

features: Cortex: Lymphoid Follicles (B cells)
Germinal Centers: Pale central area of secondary follicles (B cell activation)
Paracortex: Deep cortex (T cell zone, High Endothelial Venules)
Medulla: Medullary Cords (Plasma cells, Macrophages) and Sinuses
Subcapsular Sinus: Space beneath capsule receiving afferent lymph
function: Adaptive immune response (B and T cell activation)
theory.examTips: Subcapsular Sinus is DIAGNOSTIC (space under capsule). Germinal Centers indicate active immune response. Paracortex is T-cell dependent (deleted in DiGeorge syndrome).

name: Spleen
description: The spleen filters blood. It consists of White Pulp (lymphoid nodules) and Red Pulp (blood-filled sinusoids and cords), enclosed by a capsule.

features: White Pulp: Periarteriolar Lymphoid Sheaths (PALS - T cells) + Follicles (B cells)
Central Arteriole: arteriole running through PALS (eccentric in follicle)
Red Pulp: Splenic Cords (Cords of Billroth) + Venous Sinusoids
Trabeculae: Thick connective tissue distinct from capsule
NO Cortex/Medulla distinction
theory.examTips: Identify the Central Arteriole within the White Pulp (looks like a lymph nodule). No cortex/medulla = Spleen (vs Lymph Node/Thymus). Red pulp looks 'messy' and bloody.

name: Thymus
description: The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ for T-cell maturation. It has lobules with a dark cortex and pale medulla containing Hassall's Corpuscles.

features: Lobulated architecture (separated by septa)
Cortex: Dark basophilic (packed immature T lymphocytes/thymocytes)
Medulla: Pale (mature T cells, epithelial reticular cells)
Hassall's Corpuscles: Concentric layers of keratinized epithelial cells (Medulla only)
Blood-Thymus barrier features
theory.examTips: Hassall's Corpuscles are DIAGNOSTIC (look like pink onions in the medulla). Involution: In adults, replaced by adipose tissue (fatty thymus).
